The question isn’t can you fast. The question is “Should you fast?” At 14 you should not fast. Your body and your mind are still developing and need nutrition to continue developing normally. If you are significantly overweight, go on a diet and increase your activity level. If you are not, why, on earth, would you want to fast. Fasting is an extreme measure. The key to losing weight, if that is your goal, is to reduce not only the quantity of food you consume but also change the type of food you eat to be more nutritional with fewer empty calories. I am neither a dietitian nor a medical doctor. You could do a few thing that will help. First, join a gym and go regularly. If all you do is run on the treadmill for an hour every day, you will be in better shape. If you can’t afford to join a gym, start walking a mile or more every day. Second, start counting your calories. Make sure you know how many calories are in such things as a hamburger. It is a lot more than you think. Third, find out the nutritional value of what you are eating. More fiber, less sugar and carbs, less fat. Not zero, just less. Fourth, do not adopt any crazy diet. You cannot sustain that crazy diet forever and when you quit it, you will gain almost all the weight back. Fifth, journal your food. I recommend MyFitnesspal.com. Once you’ve started it will be easy but it will be shocking when you start. This web site has a journal and will also keep track of your exercise and the calories you burn. It has healthy recipes and wonderful exercise suggestions. No, do not fast. Find some other more healthy way to accomplish what you want. I have assumed you want to lose weight.

response.answer_text: Just my 2 cents (anecdotal). If I were you I’d wait until you stop growing and then you can stop, take a good look at yourself and, as truthfully as you can, evaluate whether you really need to go on a fast or whether your current diet is meeting your dietary needs. Rough rule of thumb is around 20 years old plus or minus 2 years. At 14 you shouldn’t risk depriving yourself of nutrition if you’re already eating like you should. Later you can discuss a plan with your primary care physician or a dietician or nutrition advisor and make that part of your life style which should include your diet, exercise, sleep, and mental health (avoiding causes of too much stress). Keep in mind that as you become older (after 20) you’ll have to adjust for decrease in metabolism which (another rule of thumb) is about 1 % a year decrease after 20. So at 25 you won’t notice much difference but at 40 you might notice that if you don’t adjust with more exercise or less food you’ll begin to accumulate more weight. Exercise is important not so much to lose weight but for your body to function at its best. One thing you might not ever read is that it is important for you to be active (walk, move around, not be sedentary) because you lymph system doesn’t have much of a pump other than for you to be moving around. If you don’t move around then everything becomes more stagnant and that leads to future eventual health problems. You have to be active and it should be as much of a part of your life as brushing your teeth and personal hygiene like bathing. There are many ways so you just have to find a few that are agreeable to you.

No, children and teens should not fast, or attempt weight loss except under the explicit guidance of their doctor. You are still growing! Your body is still developing, your brain is still developing and changing. Hormones are still in flux. There are so many things going on inside your body right now, the last thing you want to do is stop feeding your body. You want to not mess anything up? Don’t fast. Don’t diet! Don’t restrict your calories. Don’t fall into this trap! Zahrah Murdock's answer to How did you lose weight as a teenager? The best thing you can do is follow the advice in my link above - begin to adopt healthy life practices, follow them until they become habits! This will be far more than weight, this will be life-long health. When you hit 20 and you think you still need to lose weight, then think about intermittent fasting.
